columns.text: In this problem, we will show the relationship between the value of an ordinary annuity and an equivalent annuity due.

Now that we have already set the assumptions, we can show the relationship for the present value:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{PV due value}&=\left(\dfrac{\text{Cashflow}}{(1+\text{Rate})^1}+\dfrac{\text{Cashflow}}{(1+\text{Rate})^2} +\ldots+ \dfrac{\text{Cashflow}}{(1+\text{Rate})^\text{Time}}\right) \times (1+\text{Rate})
\end{aligned}$$

or simply:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{PV annuity due value}&=\text{PV annuity} \times(1+\text{Rate})
\end{aligned}$$

For the future value, the perpetuity is given using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{FV of perpetuity}&=\text{Cashflow} \times(1+\text{Rate})
\end{aligned}$$

Now that we have already set the assumptions, we can show the relationship for the future value:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{FV annuity due value}&=\left(\text{Cashflow} \times(1+\text{Rate})^1 +\text{Cashflow} \times(1+\text{Rate})^2+ \ldots + \text{Cashflow} \times(1+\text{Rate})^\text{Time}\right) \times (1+\text{Rate})
\end{aligned}$$

or simply:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{FV annuity due value}&=\text{FV annuity} \times (1+\text{Rate})
\end{aligned}$$
